fields.name: J.K. Rowling
fields.biography: British author best known for the Harry Potter series, which has become one of the best-selling users series in history.

fields.name: George R.R. Martin
fields.biography: American novelist and short-story writer best known for his series A Song of Ice and Fire, adapted into the TV show Game of Thrones.

fields.name: Agatha Christie
fields.biography: English writer known for her detective novels featuring Hercule Poirot and Miss Marple.

fields.name: J.R.R. Tolkien
fields.biography: English writer, poet, and philologist best known for The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings trilogy.

fields.name: Stephen King
fields.biography: American author of horror, supernatural fiction, suspense, and fantasy novels.

fields.name: Jane Austen
fields.biography: English novelist known for her six major novels including Pride and Prejudice and Sense and Sensibility.

fields.name: Mark Twain
fields.biography: American writer and humorist famous for The Adventures of Tom Sawyer and Adventures of Huckleberry Finn.

fields.name: Ernest Hemingway
fields.biography: American novelist, short-story writer, and journalist; awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1954.

fields.name: Leo Tolstoy
fields.biography: Russian author best known for War and Peace and Anna Karenina.

fields.name: Charles Dickens
fields.biography: English writer and social critic, considered the greatest novelist of the Victorian era.
